security: Revealing that LIRING-3 is being considered a "possibly hostile" agent and detailing surveillance methods (phone tap, mail intercept, physical surveillance) could compromise the operation and endanger sources. Furthermore, the document outlines efforts to investigate LIRING-3's sources of income and links to communist activities. "Placing of a phone tap on L-3's telephone...Intercept of all mail going to LIRING-3's home address...Physical and photo surveillance of L-3 to determine any patterns of actions or contacts with suspicious persons...To discretely investigate I-3's sources of income."
summary: This memorandum discusses the handling of LIRING-3, potentially a hostile agent, suggesting increased surveillance and investigation into his activities and finances, while a separate cable details LIRING-3's contacts with Cuban officials and plans to equip ROWTON with false credentials.
summary_one_paragraph: This collection of documents outlines concerns about LIRING-3's loyalty and proposes intensified surveillance measures, including phone taps, mail intercepts, and discreet financial investigations. Wallace B. ROWTON is tasked with managing LIRING-3 and his connections, including contacts within the Cuban consulate and potential links to communist activities. The documents reveal efforts to assess LIRING-3's trustworthiness and gather information on his associates, such as Carlos Jurado and Miriam Chichay, while also detailing plans to provide ROWTON with false identification for operational purposes.
title: Handling of LIRING-3 as Hostile Agent
